abstracts.cdata!:
The Request for Inspection for the
            Tanzania Power VI Project, filed by a group of individuals
            from Tannol Holdings, Ltd., states that the International
            Development Association (IDA) has failed to follow
            operational policies.  The IDA financed an Emergency Power
            Project (EEP) in Tanzania and, according to the Requesters,
            intervened improperly and have caused great financial loss
            and injury to the Requesters. Since 1992 a consortium of two
            Canadian companies has been considering a gas field and
            pipeline project known as the Songo Songo Project. Under the
            terms of this project, one of the consortium members, Ocelot
            Energy and Transcanada Pipelines (OTC) would be given 50
            percent interest in the gas field that is being developed
            with IDA money. The project was projected to be funded by
            private funds, but in early 1995 a letter from the Bank to
            the Tanzania Ministry of Water, Energy and Materials stated
            that all World Bank aid would be cut off unless the Canadian
            OTC project with IDA funding was selected. Despite repeated
            reassurance from the Bank that the matter would be justified
            or countermanded, the Tanzanian Ministry of Water and Energy
            announced that the OTC project had been selected. The
            Requesters claim the IDA failed to follow operational
            policies and providing funding for a government-owned power
            plant when a private sector project could have been
            constructed from private sources. The Requesters also cite
            the failure to follow environmental assessments used by the
            Bank because the OTC project will be constructed on an
            unsound site with no previous environmental assessments and
            at a cost to public health and safety.
